webTitle: Mothercare drops 5% ahead of trading update

fields.standfirst: Cantor issues sell note and cuts target price in expectation of poor performance
fields.body:
Mothercare has been struggling recently, with concerns about its poorly performing UK stores as well as its international business, talk that its Early Learning Centre could be on the block, and the departure of chief executive Simon Calver after a profit warning.

The company appointed ex-Shop Direct boss Mark Newton-Jones as its interim chief executive but it still appears to be some way from a revival.

Ahead of a trading update on Thursday covering the 12 weeks to the end of March, its shares have slumped 9p or more than 5% to 163p as Cantor Fitzgerald issued a sell note and outlined the company's problems. Analyst Mike Dennis said:

We expect another poor trading update with a 7% fall in UK like for like sales (the third quarter was down 4%) and total UK sales down 13% with Direct (on-line sales) down 5% (third quarter, down 1%).
International sales are expected to be down 1% and up 3% in local currency, similar to the third quarter. The interim chief executive has in our view numerous challenges to confront. There is room for further downgrades if trading has continued to deteriorate and costs have been incurred trying to sell Early Learning Centre. We are cutting our target price by 25% to 151p (from 200p)... as we expect further downside risk from the fourth quarter trading update and 2015 results... Furthermore, our cut in target price reflects our view that there is limited upside to the Mothercare business in 2014/15 and a risk that a new strategy and chief executive will be harder to find. In our view, the most important issue to address is the lack of UK sales growth or improvement in sales densities across an over rented store base. Mothercare (excluding Direct from Home) has continually reported negative like for like sales since January 2010 and worse still steadily falling sales densities. In addition, the level of price discounts has led to gross profit falling faster than total cost savings or the benefit of closing loss making stores. We believe another major issue is Early Learning Centre (ELC), which is rapidly becoming a liability, not an asset. UK ELC sales could fall by 18% to around £95m this year (2013 £116m) and trading losses increase to an estimated £8m, excluding central costs, across less than 40 ELC stores and 120 plus inserts in Mothercare shops. ELC was bought and integrated by Mothercare for £113m in 2007 and the goodwill is valued at £26.8m on the balance sheet (and £9.5m of trade name goodwill). It has been reported in the financial media that ELC has been offered for sale by Lazard to numerous retailers (please note this is unsubstantiated) and we believe there has been a potential management buyout, although we think it could cost Mothercare to exit ELC and incur a further write-down of goodwill expose shareholders to a negative net asset value per share. Furthermore, the international franchise business is showing signs of slowing growth potential as franchisees are taking less Mothercare stock and reporting lower sales growth rates in established markets. After the closure of the Australia and New Zealand businesses, we are cautious on the growth potential of sales and profits in the Middle East (Saudi Arabia, UAE), Russia, Greece and Turkey while Mothercare and ELC only have limited exposure across about 20 countries. We already expect Mothercare's 2014 underlying pre-tax profit to be £7.3m (2013 restated to £5.9m from £8.3m) and see further risk to 2015 profits unless ELC is sold or further stores closed. In our view, Mothercare's share price still has significant downside risk as any ELC deal could lead to further asset write-downs and expose Mothercare's weak balance sheet.

webTitle: UK's 25% aid budget rise contributes to record help for developing countries

fields.standfirst: Britain meets UN target but OECD expresses concern that help for poorest countries in sub-Saharan Africa fell in 2013
fields.body:
An increase of more than 25% in Britain's aid budget lifted financial help to the world's poorest countries to record levels in 2013.

Figures released by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development show that the post-crash slide in assistance came to an end, with aid rising by 6% to $134.8bn (£81bn).

Britain's overseas development assistance climbed by 27.8% as the government met the United Nations target of allocating 0.7% of national output to aid for the first time.

But the report from the OECD's Development Assistance Committee revealed that help to the poorest countries in sub-Saharan Africa fell last year.

"It is heartening to see governments increasing their development aid budgets again, despite the financial constraints they are currently facing," said the OECD's secretary general, Angel Gurría. "However, assistance to some of the neediest countries continues to fall, which is a serious concern."

The Paris-based think tank said the signs were that aid would increase again in 2014 before stabilising. Financial help rose steadily from 1997 to 2010 before being cut back as western governments imposed austerity measures.

The last Labour government made a commitment to the 0.7% aid target and the pledge was reaffirmed by the coalition, which ringfenced the Department of International Development from spending cuts. The DfID budget was not increased in 2011 and 2012 but rose sharply last year.

Britain joined Denmark, Luxembourg, Norway, Sweden and the United Arab Emirates in meeting the UN target. The Netherlands fell below 0.7% for the first time since 1974.

Bilateral aid to sub-Saharan Africa stood at $26.2bn (£15.8bn), a decrease of 4% in real terms from 2012. Aid to the African continent fell by 5.6% to $28.9bn. Excluding debt relief, which was high in 2012 due to assistance to Côte d'Ivoire, net aid in real terms rose by 1.2% to sub-Saharan Africa but fell by 0.9% to the continent as a whole.

webTitle: Vodafone lifted by positive JP Morgan comments

fields.standfirst: Bank says improving performance across southern Europe should help revenue growth
fields.body:
Vodafone shares have been drifting lower following the cash return to shareholders after the sale of its Verizon Wireless stake.

Hopes of a bid from AT&T have faded, while there are worries about outlook for future growth. But the mobile operator's shares have edged 0.35p higher to 217.95p after an upbeat note from JP Morgan Cazenove. The bank's analysts have put an overweight rating on the shares with a 270p price target, saying:

Vodafone shares have underperformed the FTSE by 10% over the last six weeks as regulatory and M&A hopes have begun to fade. Against this backdrop Vodafone's full year results should offer a floor. We expect the fourth quarter to highlight a 1 percentage point sequential improvement in organic service revenue growth underpinned by an easing mobile termination rates drag and modest underlying improvements across southern Europe. Furthermore we expect March 2015 guidance to support our EBITDA and free cashflow forecasts offering investors greater forecast visibility.
On an underlying basis, we anticipate a small trend deterioration in Italy (albeit recent price increases should see this prove short lived), a stable performance in Germany (it's too early for recent investments to bear fruit), and improvements across Egypt, Portugal, Spain.

webTitle: FTSE 100 falters after mixed tech stock performance but mining shares give support

fields.standfirst: Rise in Chinese markets lifts mining sector but investors remain nervous on outlook
fields.body:
Leading shares are edging lower after a mixed performance from technology stocks, but there is some support from the mining sector to limit the losses.

Asian markets mostly followed Wall Street lower after a second day of sharp falls in the US ahead of the start of its reporting season later in the day, with Alcoa first on the block. But Chinese shares closed at their highest level for seven weeks on Tuesday after a holiday the day before, lifted by financial shares.

The Chinese rise lifted mining shares, with Antofagasta adding 8.5p to 860p and Rio Tinto rising 33.5p to £33.77.

But mid-cap Ukrainian iron ore miner Ferrexpo has slipped 0.9p to 154.9p despite news that its output rose by 9% in the first quarter, as tensions in the area continued. Analyst Yuen Low at Shore Capital said:

As expected, the Russian standoff has not affected Ferrexpo's operations as of yet. [But] we reiterate our view that the on-going crisis can be expected to weigh on the share price until there are clear indications of resolution, even if production continues to remain unaffected.

Overall the FTSE 100, after Monday's 1% decline, has dipped another 13.40 points to 6609.44 despite stronger than expected UK industrial output figures. Mike McCudden at Interactive Investor said:

As investors hit the panic button ahead of US earnings whilst tension in the Ukraine goes back on the boil there appears to be little information presently to warrant a move back in to equities. Whilst there may be relative calm this morning after yesterday's bloodbath investors are hanging out on the side-lines in the hope for some justification for a move back to higher ground. However, with nerves shredded and the VIX [volatility index] sitting on a high it feels like any bounce could present another gilt edged selling opportunity. Without overnight support from China influencing the FTSE weighted miners this morning we could have easily been presented another sharp selloff.

Among the hard hit technology stocks - where investors have been bailing out on concerns another bubble had developed - chipmaker Arm has recovered some ground, up 16.5p at 989p. But online grocer Ocado is down 12.2p at 409.8p.

Sports Direct International is the biggest faller in the leading index, down 57p at 836.5p after it was revealed late on Monday that founder Mike Ashley had cashed in more than £200m worth of shares in the business.

Associated British Foods has fallen 103p to £26.50, with some traders suggesting the decline was prompted by a profit warning from German sugar producer Suedzucker.

Without overnight support from China influencing the FTSE weighted miners this morning we could have easily been presented another sharp selloff. webTitle: More rate cuts expected as Australian unemployment heads for 11-year high

fields.standfirst: NAB survey reports optimism at its lowest level since last year's federal election as sluggish economy takes its toll
fields.body:
Australia’s sluggish economy could need further rate cuts by the end of the year as unemployment looks set to hit an 11-year high, economists have warned.

Business confidence fell from seven points in February to four in March, according to the National Australia Bank monthly survey on Tuesday. Business conditions remained subdued but lifted slightly to one point in March.

Optimism was at its lowest level since its post-federal election bounce last year and mining was the least confident industry, the report said.

"Rather than conditions rising to confirm the improvement in confidence, it seems that confidence is beginning to succumb to the continuing softness in conditions," NAB economists said.

With unemployment figures on Thursday expected to show the jobless rate at 6.1%, its highest since 2003, the authors of the report believe that the Reserve Bank of Australia may be forced to reduce the cost of borrowing again.

RBA governor Glenn Stevens has already reduced the cash rate eight times since November 2011 in an effort to stimulate the non-mining sectors of the economy.

“We’ve been anticipating one last rate cut,” said Rob Brooker, NAB’s head of Australian economics and commodities. “Nothing we have seen so far would cause us to revise that.”

Although the survey showed that confidence had improved since last year, the labour market was still weak, Brooker said. The mining sector continued to shed jobs as construction projects tailed off and the federal government cut jobs.

Most industries did experience improved conditions in March, except the transport and utilities and wholesale industries, the report said.

The wholesale industry, which NAB considers a bellwether industry, deteriorated heavily and was by far the weakest, while recreation and personal services saw the best conditions.

Although there had been pockets of improvement in the economy, a more broad-based pick-up was needed to sustain current confidence levels, NAB economists said.

webTitle: Coles admits misleading customers on benefits to farmers during 'milk wars'

fields.standfirst: Competition watchdog says supermarket will publish corrections over social media campaign that presented estimates as fact
fields.body:
Coles has admitted it is likely it misled customers when it dropped the price of its milk and claimed more money would go in the pockets of farmers, the Australian consumer watchdog has revealed.

The supermarket giant has accepted a court enforceable undertaking to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), after an investigation into a social media campaign found Coles made claims using data that was directly contradicted by other existing studies.

The ACCC said Coles either did know, or should have known, about the alternative studies at the time it published its “our Coles brand milk story” campaign.

Coles dropped the price of two litres of its milk to $2 in January 2011 amid intense debate about the so-called “milk wars", and ran its cartoon and video across numerous platforms from February 2013 to May of the same year.

In the campaign, Coles lauded the price drop, and claimed the company would absorb the profit loss, with the share that went to farmers actually increasing. The ACCC began investigating the claims after a number of complaints were received from dairy farmer organisations.

“Coles represented in a video and cartoon on social media that the farmgate milk price increased from 86 cents per two-litre bottle of Coles-brand milk in 2010-11 to around 90 cents in 2011-12, when in fact this was an estimate and final industry figures showed the 2011-12 farmgate milk price actually decreased to 84 cents,” said the ACCC’s chairman, Rod Sims.

“The ACCC was concerned that Coles presented estimates and opinions as facts and that a number of representations made in the video and cartoon could not be substantiated by Coles,” Sims said.

The data on which Coles based its claim was from early estimates of an increase in the milk price in an August 2012 report. However the ACCC said Coles either was or should have been aware of other existing reports at the time it published which predicted a decrease. Final figures ultimately found there was a decrease.

The ACCC found Coles made two misrepresentations, including that it was a “fact” that during 2010-11 and 2011-12 Coles reduced its margin on average and processors received about $1 per two litres of Coles-branded milk.

“In fact, these figures were estimates that were unable to be substantiated,” said the ACCC.

It also found Coles portrayed as a fact that its price cuts would directly result in increased consumption of milk.

“Any implied connection between lower retail milk prices and increased production of milk was only an opinion, which ignored the impact of other relevant factors on milk production,” said the ACCC.

Coles told Guardian Australia it maintains that the “key message in the video around funding of the retail price cut was correct”.

However it accepted “that some of the supporting information was based on estimates which were subsequently updated and therefore could not be substantiated".

The Australian Dairy Farmers association welcomed the ACCC finding, and labelled the campaign a “slap in the face” for dairy farmers, in addition to the damage it claimed was already inflicted by the price drop to $1.

“The video and cartoon were a cynical exercise by Coles to convince consumers that farmgate prices had increased for dairy farmers when they had actually decreased,” said an ADF board member, Chris Griffin.

“The ACCC’s ruling is an indictment of Coles and undermines their key claim that they have absorbed the cost of $1 per litre milk.”

As part of the undertaking, Coles must publish corrections on all platforms on which the original cartoon and video appeared, review its consumer law compliance, and refrain from making deceptive or misleading claims regarding milk products for three years or the ACCC could take it to court.

The ACCC suggested Coles should place the same level of concern for consumer law compliance when conducting social media campaigns as traditional advertising.
